content:
Try this, it should make for more consistency:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General > Language & Appearance > Fonts > Advanced button

- at the top, set 'Fonts for:' to Latin if it isn't already

- change Proportional and Monospace fonts/sizes

- set Minimum font size to None

- at the top, change set 'Fonts for:' to Other Writing Systems

- repeat the process of changing fonts/sizes

- at the bottom, make sure 'Allow messages to use other fonts' is disabled if desired > OK > close the popup

- set TB menu > Settings > Composition > HTML Style to Variable Width and Medium font

content:
When setting up the font size for composing: go to TB menu > Settings > General > Language & Appearance > Fonts > Advanced button

re : change Proportional and Monospace fonts/sizes - I had both of these set to 16.

Yes that 16 means 16px and whatever you set will be regarded as 'Medium' font size and used when composing.

re :I had set Minimum font size to 16. It's now set to None.

I do not recommend that because you are already thinking that size 16 is too small to use as 'medium'. Setting to none means if people send using a tint font you may have difficulty reading it, so I would recommend setting 14 to force tiny font to be a size 14.

Remember - whatever you set for 'Latin' must also be set for 'Other Writing Systems' this means both western encoding and unicode encoding will use same settings.

General font size used in Folder Pane, Thread Pane Menus etc can be set here: Menu app icon (3 lines) > Font Size - default is 12, so click on the + icon to increase size. Keep clicking until you have a good reading size.

In Settings > Composing If you want to use Body text as default when composing:

  • uncheck 'Use Paragraph format instead of body text'

FWIW, these settings work for me on a 27" 1440p monitor.

cheers P

Ps if i have screwed something up, please let me know.

content:
Date le molte segnalazioni le informazioni e gli aggiornamenti su questo problema sono raccolte in questa pagina -> https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php?topic=79683.0

Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

Potresti fare questa verifica?

  1. Apri Thunderbird
  2. Fai click su Nuovo messaggio
  3. Ora usa la combinazione di tasto Alt + TAB per vedere quali finestre sono aperte in Windows

Vedi finestre secondarie riferite a Thunderbird?
creator: @next

content:
I have come across some people who experienced oversized pop windows for various things being too large and checking the following settings are using the default sorted out the problem. See if this is effecting you.

Please check the following:

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to bottom
  • click the 'Config editor' button
  • It opens in a new tab
  • In search type: perpx
  • look for: layout.css.devPixelsPerPx
  • default has negative number -1.0 setting
  • click on the pencil icon
  • Remove the current setting and type : -1.0
  • click on the tick icon to save.

Restart Thunderbird

content:
Hi Gilles, for the time being I advise to stay with TB 128.11.1esr as your "working" TB and its profile. For testing TB 140.0.1esr in a new profile proceed as follows: • install version TB 140.0.1esr on your Desktop and not in the applications folder • in a Finder window open the user library and rename the folder "Thunderbird" to "Thunderbird-work' • now start TB 140.0.1esr which will create a new folder "thunderbird" in your user-library and a new virgin profile xxxxxxxx.default-release. Set up one of your accounts, preferably an IMAP account • test v140.0.1esr whether or not there is the same abundant CPU consumption including TB "quitting unexpectedly" • if TB 140.0.1esr works flawlessly in its own new profile we conclude that there is something in your old TB 128-esr profile which is incompatible with TB 140.0.1esr.

When you want to return to work with v128 in your usual profile, quit TB 140.0.1esr, open your user-library, rename "thunderbird" to "thunderbird-140" and "Thunderbird-work" back to "Thunderbird". Then start TB 128.11.1esr which will open in your usual working profile....
creator: Mapenzi

content: The authentication for the incoming server is set in Account Settings, Server Settings, and at the bottom of the left pane of Account Settings in Outgoing Server (SMTP). If you have completed the OAuth2 process, an oauth:// token is automatically stored in Saved Passwords. That token should be automatically read whenever TB starts, for both receiving and sending.

content: This is controlled by a file named popstate.dat within the profile in the mail\<POPaccount> folder. If you delete that file, thunderbird will start from scratch. That may not be what you want, but I wanted to share the info, just in case.

content:

Looking at the format, each line seems to consist of 3 elements

  • a single letter "k" in all cases
  • A 16 digit hexadecimal number
  • a timestamp in Unix epoch format

I wonder if each of those is a message ID and the time it was downloaded so If I deleted the enties corresponding to the gap, Thunderbird re-download those messages?

content: The addressbook and account data are in the profile, but it is up to the user to do backups. Thunderbird does not have a cloud where it keeps copies of user accounts. There are such services, but there is a fee for them.

content: I know eM Client does a nice backup, but it's to the hard drive. Mailbird doesn't offer one that I'm aware of. TheBat! has a nice autobackup feature, but I don't recall if it's to the cloud or the same hard drive. You might pursue something such as Idrive, which offers a very low fee for daily backups, but you must first define the folders to be backed up (up to 5 gig is free) - and I've had great success with them for years. And there are others... BUT, I regularly see automated backups fail on this forum, mostly because they are done while Thunderbird is running and it has hold of the files so resulting backups are corrupted. If you pursue that route, I encourage setting the auto backup to run during time when you're not using thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content:
Yes, when windows crashes everything is lost. That is why i recommend periodically doing full backup to prevent disaster. Simple steps, really: here is the info in brief steps:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: thunderbird does. IMAP accounts sync to the server. if the server appears empty, thunderbird syncs the PC hard drive accordingly. Then, when the IMAP account content is available, it populates to the PC. Never assume that what is on the PC is a backup because it isn't; it's the reflection of the server. If you want the content on PC to be a backup, then you need to COPY it to local folders.
creator: davidsk

content: In your profile, in the Mail\<POPaccount> folder, is a file named popstate.dat. This file keeps Thunderbird aware of last downloaded message so that it doesn't do what you described. It may be that the file is now read-only, or somehow corrupted.

content:
Generally because you have opted to have you outgoing mail scanned and your antivirus does not use a recognized encryption certificate. Although in this instance it may be because you are using a hosted server without an encryption certificate for the domain.

What do you see about the server in the certificate when you view it? Issued by your antivirus? or for another server entirely that is related to the hosting service that you trust. You are seeing it because there is an anomaly and the software wants you to make a decision about what is to be done.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The details you offer in your posts is getting worse over the years.

So please take the time to explain what the issue is and with what mail provider. A few years ago you were having issues with an old roadrunner address. Which spectrum obviously fixed. What are the details now?
creator: MattAuSupport
